text: Human monocytes isolated from peripheral blood of healthy donors show a time - dependent differentiation into macrophages upon in vitro cultivation , closely mimicking their in vivo migration and maturation into extravascular tissues .
The mediator ( s ) of this maturation process has not been yet defined .

We investigated the involvement of signal transducers and activators of transcription ( STAT ) factors in this phenomenon and reported the specific , time - dependent , activation of <extra_id_0> STAT1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> protein starting at day 0 / 1 of cultivation and maximally expressed at day 5 .

text: Moreover , the effect of cell adhesion to <extra_id_0> fibronectin <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> or laminin was studied to investigate mechanisms involved in <extra_id_0> STAT1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> activation .

Compared with monocytes adherent on plastic surfaces , freshly isolated cells allowed to adhere either to <extra_id_0> fibronectin <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - or laminin-coated flasks exhibited an increased <extra_id_0> STAT1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> binding activity both in control and in <extra_id_0> IFN-gamma <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - treated cells .
